name: Homemade English Muffins
description: Classic English muffins with characteristic nooks and crannies, ideal for Eggs Benedict.
instructions: Activate Yeast: In a small bowl, combine yeast, sugar, and 1/4 cup of the warm milk. Let stand for 5 minutes until foamy.
Mix Dough: In a large bowl (or stand mixer bowl), whisk together bread flour and salt. Add the yeast mixture, remaining 1 cup warm milk, and melted butter. Stir until a shaggy dough forms.

Knead: Turn dough onto a lightly floured surface. Knead for 8–10 minutes until smooth, elastic, and slightly tacky. (Alternatively, use a stand mixer with a dough hook on medium-low speed for 6-8 minutes).
First Rise: Place dough in a lightly greased bowl, turning to coat. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a damp cloth. Let rise in a warm place for 1 to 1.5 hours, or until doubled in size.
Shape: Gently punch down the risen dough. Turn out onto a surface lightly dusted with cornmeal. Roll or pat the dough out to about ½-inch thickness.
Cut: Using a 3½-inch round cutter, cut out about 8 muffins. Dust the tops lightly with more cornmeal.
Second Rest: Place the cut muffins on a baking sheet generously dusted with cornmeal, ensuring they don't touch. Cover loosely with plastic wrap or a cloth. Let rest for 30 minutes.

Cook: Heat a large, dry cast-iron skillet or griddle over medium-low heat. Carefully place muffins onto the hot skillet (do not overcrowd). Cook for 5–7 minutes per side, until golden brown and cooked through (internal temperature should reach ~200°F/93°C). Adjust heat as needed to prevent burning; they cook slowly.
Cool: Transfer cooked muffins to a wire rack to cool completely.
Serve: Split muffins horizontally with a fork (not a knife) to preserve the nooks and crannies just before toasting or serving.
cookNotes: Cook low and slow for even browning and proper internal cooking.
Splitting with a fork creates the best texture.
Store cooled muffins in an airtight container for a few days or freeze.
